revision.text:
{{about|hypothetical faster-than-light particles|quantum fields with imaginary mass|Tachyonic field|other uses}} [[File:Tachyon04s.gif|thumb|250px|Because a tachyon would always travel faster-than-light, it would not be possible to see it approaching. After a tachyon has passed nearby, an observer would be able to see two images of it, appearing and departing in opposite directions. The black line is the shock wave of [[Cherenkov radiation]], shown only in one moment of time. This double image effect is most prominent for an observer located directly in the path of a superluminal object (in this example a sphere, shown in grey). The right hand bluish shape is the image formed by the blue-doppler shifted light arriving at the observer — who is located at the apex of the black Cherenkov lines — from the sphere as it approaches. The left-hand reddish image is formed from red-shifted light that leaves the sphere after it passes the observer. Because the object arrives before the light, the observer sees nothing until the sphere starts to pass the observer, after which the image-as-seen-by-the-observer splits into two—one of the arriving sphere (to the right) and one of the departing sphere (to the left).]]
A '''tachyon''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|t|æ|k|i|ɒ|n}}) or '''tachyonic particle''' is a hypothetical [[particle]] that always travels [[faster-than-light|faster than light]]. Most physicists believe that faster-than-light particles cannot exist because they are not consistent with the known laws of physics.<ref name=Randall/><ref name=Tipler/> If such particles did exist, they could be used to build a [[tachyonic antitelephone]] and send signals faster than light, which (according to [[special relativity]]) would lead to violations of [[causality (physics)|causality]].<ref name=Tipler/> No experimental evidence for the existence of such particles has been found.
The possibility of particles moving faster-than-light was first proposed by O. M. P. Bilaniuk, V. K. Deshpande, and [[George Sudarshan|E. C. G. Sudarshan]] in 1962, although the term they used for it was "meta-particle".<ref name=sudarshan62/> In the 1967 paper that coined the term,<ref name="Feinberg67"/> [[Gerald Feinberg]] proposed that tachyonic particles could be quanta of a [[Quantum field theory|quantum field]] with imaginary mass. However, it was soon realized that excitations of such [[Tachyonic field|imaginary mass fields]] do ''not'' under any circumstances propagate faster than light,<ref name="susskind"/> and instead the imaginary mass gives rise to an instability known as [[tachyon condensation]].<ref name=Randall/> Nevertheless, in modern physics the term "tachyon" often<ref name=Randall/><ref name=Sen/> refers to imaginary mass fields rather than to faster-than-light particles. Such fields have come to play a [[Tachyonic field#Importance in physics|significant role in modern physics]].
The term comes from the {{lang-el|[[Wiktionary:ταχύ|ταχύ]]}}, ''tachy'', meaning "rapid". The complementary particle types are called [[massless particle|luxons]] (which always move at the [[speed of light]]) and [[bradyons]] (which always move slower than light); both of these particle types are known to exist.
== Tachyons in relativity theory == In [[special relativity]], a faster-than-light particle would have [[space-like]] [[four-momentum]],<ref name=Feinberg67 /> in contrast to ordinary particles that have [[time-like]] [[four-momentum]]. Although in some theories the mass of tachyons is regarded as [[imaginary number|imaginary]], in some modern formulations the mass is considered real,<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Recami|first=E.|date=2007-10-16|title=Classical tachyons and possible applications|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/BF02724327|journal=Rivista del Nuovo Cimento|language=en|volume=9|issue=6|pages=1–178|doi=10.1007/BF02724327|issn=1826-9850|bibcode=1986NCimR...9e...1R}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Vieira|first=R. S.|date=|title=An introduction to the theory of tachyons|journal=Rev. Bras. Ens. Fis.|volume=34|issue=3|doi=|pmid=|access-date=|via=|arxiv=1112.4187|bibcode=2011arXiv1112.4187V}}</ref><ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Hill|first=James M.|last2=Cox|first2=Barry J.|date=2012-12-08|title=Einstein's special relativity beyond the speed of light|url=http://rspa.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/468/2148/4174|journal=Proc. R. Soc. A|language=en|volume=468|issue=2148|pages=4174–4192|doi=10.1098/rspa.2012.0340|issn=1364-5021|bibcode=2012RSPSA.468.4174H}}</ref> the formulas for the momentum and energy being redefined to this end. Moreover, since tachyons are constrained to the [[spacelike]] portion of the energy–momentum graph, they could not slow down to subluminal speeds.<ref name="Feinberg67"/>
=== Mass === {{main|Mass#Tachyonic particles and imaginary (complex) mass|Tachyonic field}} In a [[Lorentz invariant]] theory, the same formulas that apply to ordinary slower-than-light particles (sometimes called "[[bradyon]]s" in discussions of tachyons) must also apply to tachyons. In particular the [[energy–momentum relation]]: :<math>E^2 = (pc)^2+ (mc^2)^2 \;</math> (where '''p''' is the relativistic [[momentum]] of the bradyon and '''m''' is its [[rest mass]]) should still apply, along with the formula for the total energy of a particle: :<math>E = \frac{mc^2}{\sqrt{1 - \frac{v^2}{c^2}}}.</math> This equation shows that the total energy of a particle (bradyon or tachyon) contains a contribution from its rest mass (the "rest mass–energy") and a contribution from its motion, the kinetic energy. When ''v'' is larger than ''c'', the denominator in the equation for the energy is [[imaginary number|"imaginary"]], as the value under the [[square root|radical]] is negative. Because the total [[energy]] must be [[real number|real]],{{Dubious |Mass |reason=If we can allow the mass to be imaginary, why does the energy have to be real?? |date=August 2015}} the numerator must ''also'' be imaginary: i.e. the [[rest mass]] '''m''' must be imaginary, as a pure imaginary number divided by another pure imaginary number is a real number.
In some modern formulations of the theory, the mass of tachyons is regarded as real.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2" />
=== Speed === One curious effect is that, unlike ordinary particles, the speed of a tachyon ''increases'' as its energy decreases. In particular, <math> E </math> approaches zero when <math> v </math> approaches infinity. (For ordinary [[Bradyon|bradyonic matter]], ''E'' increases with increasing speed, becoming arbitrarily large as ''v'' approaches ''c'', the [[speed of light]]). Therefore, just as bradyons are forbidden to break the light-speed barrier, so too are tachyons forbidden from slowing down to below ''c'', because infinite energy is required to reach the barrier from either above or below
As noted by [[Einstein]], [[Richard Chace Tolman|Tolman]], and others, [[special relativity]] implies that faster-than-light particles, if they existed, [[Tachyonic antitelephone|could be used to communicate backwards in time]].<ref name=Benford/>
=== Neutrinos === In 1985, Chodos proposed that [[neutrino]]s can have a tachyonic nature.<ref name=Chodos/> The possibility of standard model particles moving at superluminal speeds can be modeled using [[Lorentz invariance]] violating terms, for example in the [[Standard-Model Extension]].<ref name=Colladay/><ref> {{cite journal |last1=Colladay |first1=D. |last2=Kostelecky |first2=V. A. |date=1998 |title=Lorentz-Violating Extension of the Standard Model |journal=[[Physical Review D]] |volume=58 |issue=11 |pages=116002 |arxiv=hep-ph/9809521 |bibcode=1998PhRvD..58k6002C |doi=10.1103/PhysRevD.58.116002 }}</ref><ref> {{cite journal |last=Kostelecky |first=V. A. |date=2004 |title=Gravity, Lorentz Violation, and the Standard Model |journal=[[Physical Review D]] |volume=69 |issue=10 |pages=105009 |arxiv=hep-th/0312310 |bibcode=2004PhRvD..69j5009K |doi=10.1103/PhysRevD.69.105009 }}</ref> In this framework, neutrinos experience [[Lorentz-violating neutrino oscillations|Lorentz-violating oscillations]] and can travel faster than light at high energies. This proposal was strongly criticized.<ref> {{Cite journal|doi=10.1016/0370-2693(90)90275-B|pages= 95–100|title= Against tachyonic neutrinos|journal= Physics Letters B|volume= 244|year= 1990|last1= Hughes|first1= Richard J|last2= Stephenson|first2= G.J|bibcode= 1990PhLB..244...95H}} </ref>
=== Cherenkov radiation === A tachyon with an electric charge would lose energy as [[Čerenkov radiation|Cherenkov radiation]]<ref> {{cite web |last1 = Bock |first1 = R. K. |date = 9 April 1998 |title = Cherenkov Radiation |url = http://rd11.web.cern.ch/RD11/rkb/PH14pp/node26.html |work = The Particle Detector BriefBook |publisher = [[CERN]] |accessdate = 2011-09-23 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071218162544/http://rd11.web.cern.ch/RD11/rkb/PH14pp/node26.html |archivedate = 18 December 2007 |df = }}</ref>—just as ordinary charged particles do when they exceed the local speed of light in a medium (other than a hard vacuum). A charged tachyon traveling in a vacuum, therefore, undergoes a constant [[proper time]] acceleration and, by necessity, its [[worldline]] forms a [[hyperbola]] in space-time. However reducing a tachyon's energy ''increases'' its speed, so that the single hyperbola formed is of ''two'' oppositely charged tachyons with opposite momenta (same magnitude, opposite sign) which annihilate each other when they simultaneously reach infinite speed at the same place in space. (At infinite speed, the two tachyons have no energy each and finite momentum of opposite direction, so no conservation laws are violated in their mutual annihilation. The time of annihilation is frame dependent.)
Even an electrically neutral tachyon would be expected to lose energy via gravitational [[Cherenkov radiation]], because it has a gravitational mass, and therefore increase in speed as it travels, as described above. If the tachyon interacts with any other particles, it can also radiate Cherenkov energy into those particles. Neutrinos interact with the other particles of the [[Standard model of particle physics|Standard Model]], and Andrew Cohen and [[Sheldon Glashow]] recently used this to argue that the [[faster-than-light neutrino anomaly]] cannot be explained by making neutrinos propagate faster than light, and must instead be due to an error in the experiment.<ref name=Cohen>{{cite journal |author=Cohen, Andrew G. |author2=Glashow, Sheldon L. |last-author-amp=yes|title= Pair Creation Constrains Superluminal Neutrino Propagation | journal= Phys. Rev. Lett.| volume = 107|issue=18 | pages = 181803| doi = 10.1103/PhysRevLett.107.181803| date = 2011|arxiv = 1109.6562 |bibcode = 2011PhRvL.107r1803C |pmid=22107624}}</ref>
=== Causality === [[causality (physics)|Causality]] is a fundamental principle of physics. If tachyons can transmit information faster than light, then according to relativity they violate causality, leading to logical paradoxes of the [[Grandfather paradox|"kill your own grandfather"]] type. This is often illustrated with thought experiments such as the [[Tachyonic antitelephone|"tachyon telephone paradox"]]<ref name=Benford/> or "logically pernicious self-inhibitor."<ref name=Fitzgerald/>
The problem can be understood in terms of the [[relativity of simultaneity]] in special relativity, which says that different [[inertial frame of reference|inertial reference frames]] will disagree on whether two events at different locations happened "at the same time" or not, and they can also disagree on the order of the two events (technically, these disagreements occur when the [[Spacetime#Spacetime intervals|spacetime interval]] between the events is 'space-like', meaning that neither event lies in the future [[light cone]] of the other).<ref name="Jarrell"> {{cite web |last1=Mark |first1=J. |title=The Special Theory of Relativity |url=http://www.physics.uc.edu/~jarrell/COURSES/ELECTRODYNAMICS/Chap11/chap11.pdf |pages=7–11 |publisher=[[University of Cincinnati]] |accessdate=2006-10-27 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060913173236/http://www.physics.uc.edu/~jarrell/COURSES/ELECTRODYNAMICS/Chap11/chap11.pdf |archivedate=2006-09-13 }}</ref>
If one of the two events represents the sending of a signal from one location and the second event represents the reception of the same signal at another location, then as long as the signal is moving at the speed of light or slower, the mathematics of simultaneity ensures that all reference frames agree that the transmission-event happened before the reception-event.<ref name="Jarrell"/> However, in the case of a hypothetical signal moving faster than light, there would always be some frames in which the signal was received before it was sent so that the signal could be said to have moved backward in time. Because one of the two fundamental [[postulates of special relativity]] says that the laws of physics should work the same way in every inertial frame, if it is possible for signals to move backward in time in any one frame, it must be possible in all frames. This means that if observer A sends a signal to observer B which moves faster than light in A's frame but backwards in time in B's frame, and then B sends a reply which moves faster than light in B's frame but backwards in time in A's frame, it could work out that A receives the reply before sending the original signal, challenging causality in ''every'' frame and opening the door to severe logical paradoxes.<ref name=Gron/> Mathematical details can be found in the [[tachyonic antitelephone]] article, and an illustration of such a scenario using [[Minkowski diagram|spacetime diagrams]] can be found in ''Baker, R. (2003)''<ref>. {{cite web |last=Baker |first1=R. |date=12 September 2003 |title=Relativity, FTL and causality |url=http://www.theculture.org/rich/sharpblue/archives/000089.html |work=Sharp Blue |accessdate=2011-09-23 }}</ref>
==== Reinterpretation principle ==== The '''reinterpretation principle'''<ref name="Feinberg67"/><ref name="sudarshan62"/><ref name=Gron/> asserts that a tachyon sent ''back'' in time can always be ''reinterpreted'' as a tachyon traveling ''forward'' in time, because observers cannot distinguish between the emission and absorption of tachyons. The attempt to ''detect'' a tachyon ''from'' the future (and violate causality) would actually ''create'' the same tachyon and send it ''forward'' in time (which is causal).
However, this principle is not widely accepted as resolving the paradoxes.<ref name=Benford/><ref name=Gron/><ref name=Recami/> Instead, what would be required to avoid paradoxes is that unlike any known particle, tachyons do not interact in any way and can never be detected or observed, because otherwise a tachyon beam could be modulated and used to create an anti-telephone<ref name=Benford/> or a "logically pernicious self-inhibitor".<ref name=Fitzgerald/> All forms of energy are believed to interact at least gravitationally, and many authors state that superluminal propagation in Lorentz invariant theories always leads to causal paradoxes.<ref name=Barcelo/><ref name=Arkani/>
== Fundamental models == In modern physics, all fundamental particles are regarded as excitations of [[quantum field theory|quantum fields]]. There are several distinct ways in which tachyonic particles could be embedded into a field theory.
=== Fields with imaginary mass === {{main|Tachyonic field}} In the paper that coined the term "tachyon", Gerald Feinberg studied Lorentz invariant quantum fields with imaginary mass.<ref name="Feinberg67" /> Because the [[group velocity]] for such a field is superluminal, naively it appears that its excitations propagate faster than light. However, it was quickly understood that the superluminal group velocity does not correspond to the speed of propagation of any localized excitation (like a particle). Instead, the [[negative mass]] represents an instability to [[tachyon condensation]], and all excitations of the field propagate subluminally and are consistent with [[Causality (physics)|causality]].<ref name="susskind"/> Despite having no faster-than-light propagation, such fields are referred to simply as "tachyons" in many sources.<ref name=Randall/><ref name=Sen/><ref name=Greene/><ref name=Kutasov/><ref name=NOVA/><ref name=Gibbons/>
[[Tachyonic field]]s play an important role in modern physics. Perhaps the most famous is the [[Higgs boson]] of the [[Standard model of particle physics|Standard Model of particle physics]], which has an imaginary mass in its uncondensed phase. In general, the phenomenon of [[spontaneous symmetry breaking]], which is closely related to tachyon condensation, plays an important role in many aspects of theoretical physics, including the [[Ginzburg–Landau theory|Ginzburg–Landau]] and [[BCS theory|BCS]] theories of superconductivity. Another example of a tachyonic field is the tachyon of [[bosonic string theory]].<ref name=Greene/><ref name=NOVA/><ref>J. Polchinski, ''String Theory'', Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, UK (1998)</ref>
Tachyons are predicted by bosonic string theory and also the [[Super Virasoro algebra|Neveu-Schwarz]] (NS) and NS-NS sectors, which are respectively the open bosonic sector and closed bosonic sector, of [[superstring theory|RNS Superstring theory]] prior to the [[GSO projection]]. However such tachyons are not possible due to the Sen conjecture, also known as tachyon condensation. This resulted in the necessity for the GSO projection.
=== Lorentz-violating theories === In theories that do not respect [[Lorentz invariance]], the speed of light is not (necessarily) a barrier, and particles can travel faster than the speed of light without infinite energy or causal paradoxes.<ref name=Barcelo/> A class of field theories of that type is the so-called [[Standard-Model Extension|Standard Model extensions]]. However, the experimental evidence for Lorentz invariance is extremely good, so such theories are very tightly constrained.<ref name=Glashow2>{{cite journal| author = Glashow, Sheldon Lee| title = Atmospheric neutrino constraints on Lorentz violation| date = 2004}}</ref><ref name=Coleman/>
=== Fields with non-canonical kinetic term === By modifying the kinetic energy of the field, it is possible to produce Lorentz invariant field theories with excitations that propagate superluminally.<ref name="susskind" /><ref name=Arkani/> However, such theories, in general, do not have a well-defined [[Cauchy problem]] (for reasons related to the issues of causality discussed above), and are probably inconsistent quantum mechanically.
== History == The term "tachyon" was coined by [[Gerald Feinberg]] in a 1967 paper titled "Possibility of Faster-Than-Light Particles".<ref name="Feinberg67"/> He had been inspired by the science-fiction story "Beep" by [[James Blish]].<ref>"He told me years later that he had begun thinking about tachyons because he was inspired by James Blish's [1954] short story, "Beep". In it, a faster-than-light communicator plays a crucial role in a future society but has an annoying final ''beep'' at the end of every message. The communicator necessarily allows sending of signals backward in time, even when that's not your intention. Eventually, the characters discover that all future messages are compressed into that ''beep'', so the future is known, more or less by accident. Feinberg had set out to see if such a gadget was theoretically possible." pg276 of [[Gregory Benford]]'s [http://www.gwern.net/docs/2002-radiance#old-legends "Old Legends"]</ref> Feinberg studied the kinematics of such particles according to [[special relativity]]. In his paper he also introduced [[Tachyonic field|fields with imaginary mass]] (now also referred to as "tachyons") in an attempt to understand the microphysical origin such particles might have.
The first hypothesis regarding faster-than-light particles is sometimes attributed to German physicist [[Arnold Sommerfeld]] in 1904,<ref name=Sommerfeld/> and more recent discussions happened in 1962<ref name="sudarshan62"/> and 1969.<ref name="sudarshan69"/>
In September 2011, it was reported that a [[tau neutrino]] had traveled faster than the speed of light in a major release by CERN; however, later updates from CERN on the OPERA project indicate that the faster-than-light readings were resultant from "a faulty element of the experiment's fibre optic timing system".<ref> {{cite press |date = 8 June 2012 |title = Neutrinos sent from CERN to Gran Sasso respect the cosmic speed limit |url = http://press-archived.web.cern.ch/press-archived/PressReleases/Releases2011/PR19.11E.html |publisher = [[CERN]] |accessdate = 2012-06-08 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140222165941/http://press-archived.web.cern.ch/press-archived/PressReleases/Releases2011/PR19.11E.html |archivedate = 22 February 2014 |df = }}</ref>
== In fiction == {{Main|Tachyons in fiction}} Tachyons have appeared in many works of fiction. They have been used as a standby mechanism upon which many science fiction authors rely to establish [[faster-than-light]] communication, with or without reference to causality issues. The word ''tachyon'' has become widely recognized to such an extent that it can impart a science-fictional connotation even if the subject in question has no particular relation to superluminal travel (a form of [[technobabble]], akin to ''[[positronic brain]]'').
== See also == * [[Massive particle]] (bradyon, aka tardyon) * [[Massless particle]] (luxon) * [[Lorentz-violating neutrino oscillations]] * [[Retrocausality]] * [[Tachyonic antitelephone]] * [[Virtual particle]] * [[Wheeler–Feynman absorber theory]]

Regrettably, for science fiction fans, tachyons are not real physical particles that appear in nature."</ref>

[emphasis added].</ref>

G. |date=1962 |title='Meta' Relativity |journal=[[American Journal of Physics]] |volume=30 |issue=10 |pages=718 |bibcode=1962AmJPh..30..718B |doi=10.1119/1.1941773 }}</ref>

Rev. |last1 = Aharonov |first1 = Y. |last2 = Komar |first2 = A. |last3= Susskind |first3 = L. |title = Superluminal Behavior, Causality, and Instability |date = 1969 |doi = 10.1103/PhysRev.182.1400 |issue = 5 |publisher = American Physical Society |pages = 1400–1403|bibcode = 1969PhRv..182.1400A }}</ref>
<ref name=Tipler>{{cite book| last1 = Tipler| first1 = Paul A.|last2 = Llewellyn| first2 = Ralph A.| title = Modern Physics| publisher = W.H. Freeman & Co.| date = 2008| edition = 5th| location = New York | isbn = 978-0-7167-7550-8| page = 54|quote = ... so existence of particles v > c ... Called tachyons ... would present relativity with serious ... problems of infinite creation energies and causality paradoxes.}}</ref> Tachyons could be [[Tachyonic antitelephone|used to send signals faster than light]], and (according to [[special relativity]]) this leads to violations of [[causality (physics)|causality]].
}}

revision.comment: Hmgarrison moved page [[Public and Science]] to [[VA (Public & Science)]]: The organisation is known outside of Sweden as VA (Public & Science)
revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=August 2015}}
'''VA (Public & Science)''' ([[Swedish language|Swedish]]: "'''[[:sv:Vetenskap_&_Allmänhet|Vetenskap & Allmänhet]]"''') is a [[Sweden|Swedish]] non-profit [[civil society]] organisation that works to promote dialogue and openness between researchers and the public.
The organisation was founded in 2002 and is based in [[Stockholm]], [[Sweden]].
VA's members<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://v-a.se/member-organisations/|title=Member organisations - Vetenskap & Allmänhet|work=Vetenskap & Allmänhet|access-date=2018-03-08|language=sv-SE}}</ref> consist of some 80 organisations, authorities, universities, companies and associations. In addition, it has a number of individual members. The organisation is funded through membership fees, project grants and a grant from the Swedish Ministry of Education and Research.
'''VA's main aims:''' # Increase collaboration between researchers and the public. # Increase knowledge and dialogue about: #* Public perceptions of research and research needs #* Prerequisites for research, research methods and results #* Methods for science communication # Be a leading knowledge hub for public engagement and science communication # Strengthen all aspects of engagement with society; democratic, cultural as well as for the benefit and education of society
VA carries out surveys<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://v-a.se/english-portal/projects/studies/the-public/|title=The public - Vetenskap & Allmänhet|work=Vetenskap & Allmänhet|access-date=2018-03-08|language=sv-SE}}</ref> and studies with the aim of increasing knowledge about the relationships between science and society at large. This includes an annual barometer into the Swedish public's general attitudes towards science and researchers, as well as more specific studies on how opinion-forming groups in society view and use research, how researchers interact with [[society]], and [[Methodology|methods]] for dialogue on [[science]] and [[research]].
VA also arranges many events and activities aimed at stimulating dialogue between researchers and the public in new ways and in novel arenas. VA is the Swedish national co-ordinator for the [[science festival]] [http://ec.europa.eu/research/researchersnight/index_en.htm European Researchers’ Night]. The first Researchers' Night was run in [[Sweden]] in September 2005<ref>{{cite web | url = http://ec.europa.eu/research/researchersineurope/news/article_3191_en.htm | title = Stockholm ‘erupts’ with activity for European Researchers’ Night | accessdate = 2009-03-20}}</ref> and in 2017 events were run in 29 cities in Sweden.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://forskarfredag.se/europeanresearchersnight2017/|title=A night of wonder, curiosity and fun: European Researchers’ Night 2017|last=|first=|date=|work=|accessdate=2018-03-08|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> VA also organises the [http://www.forskargrandprix.se/ Researchers' Grand Prix] , a science communication competition for researchers and [http://v-a.se/in-english/projects/activity-projects/researchers%E2%80%99-night/mass-experiments/ mass experiments in schools], a [[citizen science]] initiative that engages pupils in real research. Other activities include [[Science Cafe|Science Cafés]]. VA also participates in societal debate via traditional as well as social media.
VA is currently a partner in three EU-funded [[Framework Programmes for Research and Technological Development|Horizon 2020]] projects SciShops: ''[http://www.orion-openscience.eu/ ORION], Open Responsible research and Innovation to further Outstanding Knowledge'', is aimed at fostering [[Responsible Research and Innovation|RRI]] and [[open science]] in research performing and research funding organisations. ''[http://www.scishops.eu SciShops]'' will expand the ecosystem of [[Science shop|Science Shops]] in Europe and ''BLOOM'' is aimed at raising public awareness and interest in the [[Biobased economy|bioeconomy]] through dialogue and co-creation activities.
VA is a member of EUSEA [http://www.eusea.info/ (European Science Events Association)], ECSA ([https://ecsa.citizen-science.net/ European Citizen Science Association]) and the [http://www.livingknowledge.org/ Living Knowledge] network.
'''Secretary Generals''' * 2002-2011 Camilla Modéer * 2011–present Cissi Billgren Askwall
'''Chairs''' * 2002 Majléne Westerlund Panke * 2003-2004 Lena Hjelm-Wallén * 2005-2006 Majléne Westerlund Panke * 2007-2010 Dan Brändström * 2011–present Agneta Bladh
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.v-a.se Vetenskap & Allmänhet website] * [http://forskarfredag.se/researchers-night/ Researchers' Night in Sweden] * [http://forskargrandprix.se/researchers-grand-prix-2014/ Researchers' Grand Prix]
[[Category:Scientific organizations based in Sweden]] [[Category:Science in society]]

{{Infobox award | name = The Valdemar Poulsen Gold Medal | image = | alt = | description = Outstanding research in the field of radio techniques and related fields | presenter = {{Interlanguage link multi|Danish Academy of Technical Sciences|da|3=Akademiet for de Tekniske Videnskaber}} | country = [[Denmark]] | year = 1939 | year2 = 1993 | holder_label = | holder = | website = http://www.atv.dk }} The '''Valdemar Poulsen Gold Medal''', named after radio pioneer [[Valdemar Poulsen]], was awarded each year for outstanding research in the field of radio techniques and related fields by the {{Interlanguage link multi|Danish Academy of Technical Sciences|da|3=Akademiet for de Tekniske Videnskaber}}. The award was presented on November 23, the anniversary of Poulsen's birth. The award was discontinued in 1993.<ref name = ATK> {{cite book |last= Knudsen |first= Henrik |date= 2012 |title= VISIONER, VIDEN OG VÆRDISKABELSE – EN HISTORIE OM AKADEMIET FOR DE TEKNISKE VIDENSKABER |trans-title= VISIONS, KNOWLEDGE AND VALUE CREATION - A HISTORY OF ACADEMY OF ENGINEERING SCIENCES |url= http://www.atv.dk/publikationer?download=104 |language= Danish |pages = 135 |isbn= 978-87-7836-063-2 }} </ref>
==Recipients==

Watson-Watt, Vice-President, 1950 | url = http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/stamp/stamp.jsp?arnumber=1701182 | journal = Proceedings of the IRE | publisher = | volume = 38 | issue = 2 | page = 114 | doi = 10.1109/JRPROC.1950.229819 | access-date = 12 September 2015}} </ref> * [[1947 in science|1947]] [[Ernst Alexanderson]]<ref name= ieee2> {{cite journal | last = Brittain | first = J. W. Alexanderson | url = http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/stamp/stamp.jsp?arnumber=1701182 | journal = Proceedings of the IEEE | publisher = IEEE | volume = 92 | issue = 7 | pages = 1216–1219 | doi = 10.1109/JPROC.2004.828999 | access-date = 12 September 2015}} </ref> * [[1953 in science|1953]] [[Balthasar van der Pol]]<ref name= Pol> {{cite journal | last =Cartwright | first = Mary L. | date = 1960 | title = Balthazar Van Der Pol | url = http://jlms.oxfordjournals.org/content/s1-35/3/367.full.pdf | journal = J. London Math. Soc. | publisher = Oxford Univ. Press | volume = 35 | issue = 3 | pages = 367–376 | doi = 10.1112/jlms/s1-35.3.367 | access-date = 12 September 2015}} </ref> * [[1956 in science|1956]] [[Harald T. Friis]]<ref name= Friis> {{cite journal | last = Brittain | first = J. E. | date = 1960 | title = Electrical Engineering Hall of Fame: Harald T. Friis [Scanning Our Past] | url = http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/xpl/articleDetails.jsp?arnumber=5175251&queryText=harald%20t.%20friis&newsearch=true | journal = Proceedings of the IEEE | publisher = IEEE | volume = 97 | issue = 9 | pages = 1651–1654 | doi = 10.1109/JPROC.2009.2025788 | access-date = 12 September 2015}} </ref> * [[1960 in science|1960]] [[Charles Ginsburg|Charles P. Ginsburg]]<ref name= anb> {{cite journal | last =Marc | first =David | date = February 2000 | title = Ginsburg, Charles Paulson | url = http://www.anb.org/articles/20/20-01917.html | journal = American National Biography Online | publisher = | volume = | issue = | pages = | doi = | access-date = 12 September 2015}} </ref> * [[1963 in science|1963]] [[John R. Pierce]]{{sfn|Lee|1995|p=558}} * [[1969 in science|1969]] [[Jay Wright Forrester]]{{sfn|Lee|1995|p=309}} * [[1973 in science|1973]] [[J. B. Gunn]]<ref name= AIP> {{cite journal | date = February 1973 | title = Gunn awarded Poulsen Gold Medal | url = http://www.anb.org/articles/20/20-01917.html | journal = Physics Today | publisher = American Institute of Physics | page = 63 | doi = 10.1063/1.3127958 | access-date = 12 September 2015 | volume=26}} </ref> * [[1976 in science|1976]] [[Andrew Bobeck]]<ref name = computerworld>
{{cite news |last= |first= |date= March 14, 1977 |title= Bobeck Given Award |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=Z0pfld8YlMEC&pg=PA55&lpg=PA55&dq=Valdemar+Poulsen+gold+medal+danish+academy&source=bl&ots=LoNJ3GbHYF&sig=15_h-PoGVldeHfQY-L7SYF8a6ag&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CDUQ6AEwB2oVChMIuoqiktfwxwIVhtOACh0REwrd#v=onepage&q=Valdemar%20Poulsen%20gold%20medal%20danish%20academy&f=false
|newspaper= Computerworld |access-date= 12 September 2015}} </ref>
==References== {{reflist}} {{refbegin}} * {{cite book | editor-last= Lee | editor-first= John A. N. | date= 1995 | title= International Biographical Dictionary of Computer Pioneers | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=ocx4Jc12mkgC&pg=PA309&lpg=PA309&dq=Valdemar+Poulsen+Medal+Royal+Danish+Academy+of+Sciences+and+Letters&source=bl&ots=-zRGNfWOYe&sig=pzy86NblH6x-7FdEzIzPpMPFrgA&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CDcQ6AEwBWoVChMIiYLAntTwxwIVwbeACh3VFgDp#v=onepage&q=Valdemar%20Poulsen%20Medal%20Royal%20Danish%20Academy%20of%20Sciences%20and%20Letters&f=false |dead-url= |location= |publisher= Routledge |isbn= 978-1884964473 |ref=sfn }} {{refend}}

contributor.username: Me, Myself, and I are Here

revision.text:
:''See also [[Navajo ethnobotany]] and [[Native American ethnobotany]].'' {{expand list|date=April 2013}} {{Compact ToC|side=yes|custom1=References|custom2=Bibliography|extlinks=yes}} This is a list of plants and how they are used in [[Zuni people|Zuni]] culture.
==A== *''[[Abronia fragrans]]'' (snowball sand-verbena), fresh flowers eaten for stomachaches.<ref name="Camazine_377">[[#Camazine|Camazine & Bye]], p. 377.</ref> *[[Achillea millefolium|''Achillea millefolium'' var. ''occidentalis'']] (western yarrow), the blossoms and root are chewed, and the juice applied before fire-walking or fire-eating. A [[poultice]] of the pulverized plant is mixed with water and applied to burns.<ref name="Stevenson_42">[[#Stevenson|Stevenson]], p. 42.</ref> *''[[Achnatherum hymenoides]]'' (Indian ricegrass), ground seeds used as a staple before the availability of corn.<ref name="Stevenson_67">[[#Stevenson|Stevenson]], p. 67.</ref><ref>[[#Castetter|Castetter]], p. 27.</ref> *''[[Ageratina occidentalis]]'' (western snakeroot), ingredient of "schumaakwe cakes" and used externally for rheumatism and swelling.<ref name="Stevenson_50">[[#Stevenson|Stevenson]], p. 50.</ref> *[[Alnus incana|''Alnus incana'' subsp. ''tenuifolia'']] (thinleaf alder), bark used to dye deerskin reddish brown.<ref name="Stevenson_80">[[#Stevenson|Stevenson]], p. 80.</ref> *''[[Amaranthus blitoides]]'' (mat amaranth), seeds originally eaten raw, but later ground with black corn meal, made into balls and eaten.<ref name="Stevenson_65">[[#Stevenson|Stevenson]], p. 65.</ref> *''[[Amaranthus cruentus]]'' (red amaranth), feathery part of plant ground into a fine meal and used to color ceremonial bread red.<ref name="Stevenson_87">[[#Stevenson|Stevenson]], p. 87.</ref> The crushed leaves and blossoms are moistened and rubbed on cheeks as [[Rouge (cosmetics)|rouge]].<ref name="Stevenson_83">[[#Stevenson|Stevenson]], p. 83.</ref> *''[[Ambrosia acanthicarpa]]'' (flatspine burr ragweed), an [[infusion]] of the whole plant is taken and used as wash for obstructed menstruation. The ground root is also placed in a tooth for a toothache.<ref>[[#Stevenson|Stevenson]], pp. 51–52.</ref> *[[Amsonia tomentosa|''Amsonia tomentosa'' var. ''tomentosa'']] (woolly bluestar), compound poultice of root applied with much ceremony to rattlesnake bite.<ref name="Stevenson_53">[[#Stevenson|Stevenson]], p. 53.</ref> *''[[Artemisia carruthii]]'' (Carruth's sagewort), the seeds of which are placed on coals and used as a sweat bath for body pains from a severe cold.<ref>[[#Stevenson|Stevenson]], pp. 42–43.</ref> The ground seeds are also mixed with water, made into balls, steamed and used for food.<ref name="Stevenson_65"/> These seeds are considered to be one of the most important food plants.<ref name="Castetter_21">[[#Castetter|Castetter]], p. 21.</ref> *''[[Artemisia frigida]]'' (fringed sagewort), the whole plant is made into an infusion for colds.<ref name="Stevenson_42"/> Sprigs of this plant and corn ears are attached to decorated tablets and carried by female dancers in a drama. The sprigs are also dipped in water and planted with corn so it will grow abundantly.<ref name="Stevenson_87"/> *''[[Artemisia tridentata]]'' (big sagebrush), an infusion of the leaves is used externally for body aches. The infusion is also taken as a cold medicine. It is also placed in shoes to treat [[athlete's foot]], fissures between toes, and as a foot deodorant.<ref name="Camazine_374">[[#Camazine|Camazine & Bye]], p. 374.</ref> *''[[Asclepias involucrata]]'' (dwarf milkweed), the dry powdered root of which is mixed with saliva and used for an unspecified illness.<ref name="Camazine_373">[[#Camazine|Camazine & Bye]], p. 373.</ref> The Zuni also noted that this plant is favored by jackrabbits.<ref name="Stevenson_65"/> *''[[Asclepias subverticillata]]'' (whorled milkweed), the buds of which are eaten by little boys.<ref name="Stevenson_65"/> The pods are also gathered when two-thirds ripe and the fibers are used for weaving clothing.<ref name="Stevenson_77">[[#Stevenson|Stevenson]], p. 77.</ref> The coma is made into cords and used for fastening plumes to the prayer sticks.<ref name="Stevenson_85">[[#Stevenson|Stevenson]], p. 85.</ref> *''[[Astragalus amphioxys]]'' (crescent milkvetch), the fresh or dried root chewed by medicine man before sucking snakebite and poultice applied to wound.<ref name="Camazine_376">[[#Camazine|Camazine & Bye]], p. 376.</ref> *[[Astragalus lentiginosus|''Astragalus lentiginosus'' var. ''diphysus'']] (speckledpod milkvetch), the pods of the ''diphysus'' variety are eaten fresh, boiled, or salted. They are also dried and stored for winter use.<ref name="Stevenson_65"/> *''[[Atriplex argentea]]'' (silverscale saltbush), a poultice of chewed root is applied to sores and rashes. An infusion of the root is also taken for stomachache.<ref name="Camazine_384">[[#Camazine|Camazine & Bye]], p. 384.</ref> *''[[Atriplex canescens]]'' (fourwing saltbush), an infusion of dried root and blossoms<ref name="Stevenson_44">[[#Stevenson|Stevenson]], p. 44.</ref> or a poultice of blossoms is used for ant bites.<ref name="Camazine_384"/> Twigs are also attached to prayer plumes and sacrificed to the cottontail rabbit to ensure good hunting.<ref name="Stevenson_88">[[#Stevenson|Stevenson]], p. 88.</ref> *''[[Atriplex powellii]]'' (Powell's saltweed), the seeds of which were eaten raw before the presence of corn and afterwards. They are also ground with corn meal and made into a mush.<ref name="Stevenson_66">[[#Stevenson|Stevenson]], p. 66.</ref><ref name="Castetter_22">[[#Castetter|Castetter]], p. 22.</ref>
==B==
*''[[Bahia dissecta]]'' (ragleaf bahia), the powdered plant is rubbed on affected parts for a headache, and for rheumatism.<ref>[[#Stevenson|Stevenson]], p. 62.</ref> *''[[Berula erecta]]'' (cutleaf waterparsnip), ingredient of "schumaakwe cakes" and used externally for rheumatism.<ref name="Stevenson_44"/> An infusion of whole plant used as wash for rashes and athlete's foot infection.<ref name="Camazine_379"/> *''[[Bouteloua gracilis]]'' (blue grama), Grass bunches tied together and the severed end used as a hairbrush, the other as a broom. Bunches are also used to strain goat's milk.<ref name="Stevenson_83"/>
==C== *''[[Caesalpinia jamesii]]'' (James' holdback), infusion of plant given to sheep to make them "prolific".<ref name="Stevenson_54">[[#Stevenson|Stevenson]], p. 54.</ref> *''[[Calliandra humilis]]'' (dwarf stickpea), the powdered root of which is used three times a day for rashes.<ref name="Camazine_376"/> *''[[Campanula parryi]]'' (Parry's bellflower) – blossoms are chewed, and the saliva is applied to the skin as a [[depilatory]]. A poultice of chewed root is also applied to bruises.<ref name="Stevenson_44"/> *''[[Castilleja integra]]'' (wholeleaf Indian paintbrush), root bark mixed with minerals to dye deerskin black.<ref name="Stevenson_80"/> *''[[Chaetopappa ericoides]]'' (rose heath), infusion of whole pulverized plant applied is rubbed on the body for the pain from a cold, swellings, and rheumatism. A warm infusion of the plant is also taken to hasten parturition.<ref name="Stevenson_55">[[#Stevenson|Stevenson]], p. 55.</ref> *''[[Chamaesyce albomarginata]]'' (whitemargin sandmat), leaves and roots eaten to promote lactation.<ref name="Camazine_376"/> *''[[Chamaesyce polycarpa]]'' (smallseed sandmat), warm gruel made with plant and white cornmeal taken to promote milk flow.<ref name="Stevenson_51">[[#Stevenson|Stevenson]], p. 51.</ref> *[[Chamaesyce serpyllifolia|''Chamaesyce serpyllifolia'' subsp. ''serpyllifolia'']] (thymeleaf sandmat), plant used as a [[cathartic]], an emetic, and to increase the flow of milk in a breastfeeding mother.<ref name="Stevenson_51"/> The leaves are also chewed for the pleasant taste and used to sweeten corn meal.<ref name="Stevenson_67"/> *''[[Chenopodium album]]'' (lambsquarters), young plants cooked as greens.<ref name="Castetter_16">[[#Castetter|Castetter]], p. 16.</ref> Note: This plant is not native to the Americas, and was introduced. *''[[Chenopodium graveolens]]'' (fetid goosefoot), plant steeped in water and vapor inhaled for headache.<ref name="Stevenson_45">[[#Stevenson|Stevenson]], p. 45.</ref> *''[[Chenopodium leptophyllum]]'' (narrowleaf goosefoot), young plants boiled alone or with meat and used for food.<ref name="Stevenson_66"/><ref name="Castetter_16"/> Ground seeds mixed with corn meal and salt, made into a stiff batter, formed into balls and steamed.<ref name="Stevenson_66"/> Seeds considered among the most important food plants when the Zuni reached this world.<ref name="Castetter_21"/> *''[[Cirsium ochrocentrum]]'' (yellowspine thistle), infusion of plant taken by both partners as a contraceptive.<ref name="Camazine_374"/> Infusion of whole plant taken as a [[diaphoretic]], [[diuretic]], and emetic to treat syphilis.<ref name="Camazine_374"/><ref>[[#Stevenson|Stevenson]], pp. 44–45.</ref> Infusion of fresh or dried root taken three times a day for diabetes.<ref name="Camazine_374"/> *''[[Cleome serrulata]]'' (Rocky Mountain beeplant), leaves gathered in large quantities and hung indoors to dry for winter use.<ref name="Stevenson_69">[[#Stevenson|Stevenson]], p. 69.</ref> Young leaves cooked with corn strongly flavored with chile.<ref name="Stevenson_69"/><ref>[[#Castetter|Castetter]], p. 24.</ref> Plant paste used with black mineral paint to color sticks of plume offerings to anthropic gods.<ref name="Stevenson_69"/> Whole plant except for the root used in pottery decorations.<ref name="Stevenson_82">[[#Stevenson|Stevenson]], p. 82.</ref> *[[Conyza canadensis|''Conyza canadensis'' var. ''canadensis'']] (Canadian horseweed), crushed flowers inserted in nostrils to cause sneezing, relieving [[rhinitis]].<ref name="Stevenson_55"/> *[[Coreopsis tinctoria|''Coreopsis tinctoria'' var. ''tinctoria'']] (golden tickseed), infusion of whole plant, except for the root, taken by women desiring female babies.<ref name="Stevenson_84">[[#Stevenson|Stevenson]], p. 84.</ref> Plant formerly used to make a hot beverage until the introduction of coffee by traders.<ref name="Stevenson_66"/> The blossoms are used to make a mahogany red dye for yarn.<ref name="Stevenson_80"/> *''[[Coriandrum sativum]]'' (coriander), powdered seeds ground with chile and used a condiment with meat, leaves used as a salad.<ref name="Stevenson_66"/> Note: This plant is not native to the Americas, and was introduced. *''[[Croton texensis]]'' (Texas croton), decoction of plant taken for "sick stomach", as a purgative, and as a diuretic.<ref name="Stevenson_45"/> An infusion is taken for stomachaches, for [[syphilis]], and for [[gonorrhea]].<ref name="Camazine_375">[[#Camazine|Camazine & Bye]], p. 375.</ref> Fresh or dried root chewed by medicine man before sucking snakebite and poultice applied to wound.<ref name="Camazine_376"/> *[[Cryptantha cinerea|''Cryptantha cinerea'' var. ''jamesii'']] (James' catseye), powdered root used for sore anus.<ref name="Camazine_374"/> *''[[Cryptantha crassisepala]]'' (thicksepal catseye), hot infusion of pulverized plant applied to limbs for fatigue.<ref name="Stevenson_45"/> *''[[Cucurbita foetidissima]]'' (Missouri gourd), poultice of powdered seeds, flowers and saliva applied to swellings.<ref name="Camazine_375"/> *''[[Cucurbita pepo]]'' (field pumpkin), used as an ingredient in "schumaakwe cakes" and is used externally for rheumatism and swelling. A poultice of seeds and blossoms is applied to cactus scratches.<ref>[[#Stevenson|Stevenson]], pp. 45–46.</ref> Fresh squash is cut into spiral strips, folded into hanks and hung up to dry for winter use. The blossoms are cooked in grease and used as a delicacy in combination with other foods. Fresh squash, either whole or in pieces, is roasted in ashes and used for food. The gourds made into cups, ladles and dippers and put to various uses.<ref name="Stevenson_67"/> The gourds are also worn in [[phallic]] dances symbolizing fructification or made into ceremonial rattles. Gourds are also made into receptacles for storing precious articles.<ref name="Stevenson_88"/> *''[[Cycloloma atriplicifolium]]'' (winged pigweed), seeds mixed with ground corn to make a mush.<ref name="Castetter_22"/> Tiny seeds ground, mixed with corn meal and made into steamed cakes.<ref name="Stevenson_67"/> The blossoms are chewed and rubbed all over the hands for protection.<ref name="Stevenson_84"/>
==D== *''[[Dalea compacta]]'' (compact praireclover), the root of which is made into a poultice and used for sores and rashes, and an infusion is taken for stomachache.<ref name="Camazine_376"/> *''[[Dalea lasiathera]]'' (purple praireclover), the root of which is chewed as candy, especially by children. Flowers crushed by hand and sprinkled into meat stew as a flavoring after cooking.<ref name="Stevenson_69"/> *''[[Datura wrightii]]'' (sacred thornapple), powdered root given as an anesthetic and a narcotic for surgery. Poultice of root and flower meal applied to wounds to promote healing.<ref>[[#Stevenson|Stevenson]], pp. 46, 48.</ref> The root pieces are chewed by a robbery victim to determine the identity of the thief. The powdered root is used by rain priests in a number of ways to ensure fruitful rains.<ref name="Stevenson_88"/> *''[[Dimorphocarpa wislizeni]]'' (touristplant), warm infusion of pulverized plant applied to swelling, especially the throat. Decoction of entire plant given for delirium.<ref>[[#Stevenson|Stevenson]], pp. 48–49.</ref> Infusion of taken by men to "loosen their tongues so they may talk like fools & drunken men".<ref name="Stevenson_91">[[#Stevenson|Stevenson]], p. 91.</ref> Flower and fruit eaten as an emetic for stomachaches.<ref name="Camazine_375"/>
==E== *''[[Ephedra nevadensis]]'' (Nevada jointfir), an infusion of the whole plant, except for the root, taken for [[syphilis]].<ref name="Stevenson_49">[[#Stevenson|Stevenson]], p. 49.</ref> *[[Ericameria nauseosa|''Ericameria nauseosa'' subsp. ''nauseosa'' var. ''bigelovii'']] (rubber rabbitbrush), the blossoms of which are used to make a yellow dye.<ref name="Stevenson_80"/> Stems used to make baskets.<ref>[[#Stevenson|Stevenson]], p. 81.</ref> *''[[Eriogonum alatum]]'' (winged buckwheat), root eaten as an emetic for stomachaches.<ref name="Camazine_378">[[#Camazine|Camazine & Bye]], p. 378.</ref> Infusion of powdered root taken after a fall and relieve general misery.<ref name="Stevenson_49"/> *''[[Eriogonum fasciculatum]]'' (eastern Mohave buckwheat), poultice of powdered root applied to cuts and arrow or bullet wounds. Decoction of root taken after [[parturition]] to heal lacerations. Decoction of root also taken for hoarseness and colds involving the throat.<ref name="Stevenson_49"/> *''[[Eriogonum jamesii]]'' (James' buckwheat), root soaked in water and used as a wash for sore eyes. Fresh or dried root eaten for stomachaches.<ref name="Camazine_378"/> Root carried in mouth for sore tongue, and then buried in river bottom.<ref name="Stevenson_50"/> Ground blossom powder given to ceremonial dancers impersonating anthropic gods to bring rain.<ref name="Stevenson_91"/> *''[[Erodium cicutarium]]'' (redstem stork's bill), poultice of chewed root applied to sores and rashes. Infusion of root taken for stomachache.<ref name="Camazine_376"/> *''[[Erysimum capitatum]]'' (sanddune wallflower), an infusion of the whole plant is used externally muscle aches. The flower and the fruit are also eaten as an emetic for stomachaches.<ref name="Camazine_375"/>
==G== *''[[Gaura mollis]]'' (velvetweed), fresh or dried root chewed by medicine man before sucking snakebite and poultice applied to wound.<ref name="Camazine_377"/> *''[[Glycyrrhiza lepidota]]'' (American licorice), root chewed to keep the mouth sweet and moist.<ref name="Camazine_376"/> *''[[Gossypium hirsutum]]'' (upland cotton), cotton used to make ceremonial garments.<ref name="Stevenson_77"/> Fuzz made into cords and used ceremonially.<ref>[[#Stevenson|Stevenson]], p. 92.</ref> *''[[Grindelia nuda |Grindelia nuda, aphanactis variety]]'' (curly gumweed), poultice of flower applied to ant bites.<ref name="Camazine_375"/> Fresh or dried root chewed by medicine man before sucking snakebite and poultice applied to wound.<ref name="Camazine_374"/> *''[[Gutierrezia sarothrae]]'' (broom snakeweed), infusion of blossoms taken as a [[diaphoretic]]. Infusion of blossoms taken as a diuretic for "obstinate cases". Infusion of blossoms taken to "make one strong in the limbs and muscles."<ref name="Stevenson_53"/> Infusion of whole plant used for muscle aches. Infusion of whole plant taken to increase strength for urinary retention.<ref name="Camazine_375"/>
==H== *''[[Helianthus annuus]]'' (common sunflower), fresh or dried root chewed by medicine man before sucking snakebite and poultice applied to wound.<ref name="Camazine_375"/> Compound poultice of root applied with much ceremony to rattlesnake bite.<ref>[[#Stevenson|Stevenson]], pp. 53–54.</ref> Blossoms used ceremonially for anthropic worship.<ref name="Stevenson_93"/> *''[[Hymenopappus filifolius]]'' (fineleaf hymenopappus), a poultice of chewed root with lard applied to swellings. A warm decoction of the root taken as an emetic.<ref>[[#Stevenson|Stevenson]], pp. 54–55.</ref> The root is also used as chewing gum.<ref name="Stevenson_68"/> *''[[Hymenoxys richardsonii]]'' (pingue hymenoxys), poultice of chewed root applied to sores and rashes, and an infusion of the root is used for stomachache.<ref name="Camazine_375"/>
==I== *''[[Ipomopsis longiflora|Ipomopsis longiflora, longiflora subspecies]]'' (flaxflowered gilia), poultice of dried, powdered flowers and water applied to remove hair on newborns and children.<ref name="Camazine_378"/> *''[[Ipomopsis multiflora]]'' (manyflowered gilia), powdered, whole plant applied to face for headache. Powdered plant applied to wounds. Crushed blossoms smoked in corn husks to "relieve strangulation".<ref name="Stevenson_52">[[#Stevenson|Stevenson]], p. 52.</ref> *''[[Iris missouriensis]]'' (Rocky Mountain iris), poultice of chewed root applied to increase strength of newborns and infants.<ref name="Camazine_373"/>
==J== *''[[Juniperus monosperma]]'' (oneseed juniper), poultice of chewed root applied to increase strength of newborns and infants. An infusion of the leaves is also taken for muscle aches and to prevent conception. An infusion of the leaves is also taken postpartum to prevent uterine cramps and stop vaginal bleeding.<ref name="Camazine_373"/> A simple or compound infusion of twigs at is used to promote muscular contractions at birth and used after birth to stop blood flow.<ref name="Stevenson_55"/> The wood is also used as a favorite and ceremonial firewood, and the shredded, fibrous bark is specifically used as tinder to ignite the fire sticks used for the New Year fire.<ref name="Stevenson_93">[[#Stevenson|Stevenson]], p. 93.</ref>
==K== *''[[Krascheninnikovia lanata]]'' (winterfat), poultice of ground root applied to burns and bound with cotton cloth.<ref name="Stevenson_51"/>
==L== *''[[Lactuca tatarica|Lactuca tatarica, var pulchella]]'' (blue lettuce), dried root gum used as chewing gum.<ref name="Stevenson_68">[[#Stevenson|Stevenson]], p. 68.</ref> *''[[Ligusticum porteri]]'' (Porter's licoriceroot), infusion of root used for body aches, Root chewed by medicine man and patient during curing ceremonies for various illnesses, crushed root and water used as wash and taken for sore throat.<ref name="Camazine_379">[[#Camazine|Camazine & Bye]], p. 379.</ref> *''[[Linum puberulum]]'' (plains flax), berry juice squeezed into eye for inflammation.<ref name="Stevenson_56">[[#Stevenson|Stevenson]], p. 56.</ref> *''[[Lithospermum incisum]]'' (narrowleaf gromwell), salve of powdered root applied ceremonially to swelling of any body part. Poultice of root used and decoction of plant taken for swelling and sore throat.<ref name="Stevenson_56"/> Powdered root mixed with bum branch resin and used for abrasions and skin infections. Infusion of root taken for stomachache. Infusion of root taken for kidney problems.<ref name="Camazine_374"/> Leaves bound to arrow shafts, close to the point, obscured by sinew wrapping and used in wartime.<ref name="Stevenson_93"/> *''[[Lobelia cardinalis]]'' (cardinalflower), ingredient of "schumaakwe cakes" and used externally for rheumatism and swelling.<ref name="Stevenson_56"/> *''[[Lotus wrightii]]'' (Wright's deervetch), poultice of chewed root applied to swellings caused by being witched by a bullsnake.<ref name="Camazine_376"/> *''[[Lycium pallidum]]'' (pale wolfberry), berries eaten raw when perfectly ripe or boiled and sometimes sweetened.<ref name="Stevenson_68"/> Ground leaves, twigs and flowers given to warriors for protection during war.<ref name="Stevenson_94">[[#Stevenson|Stevenson]], p. 94.</ref>
==M== *[[Machaeranthera canescens|''Machaeranthera canescens'' subsp. ''canescens'' var. ''canescens'']] (cutleaf goldenweed), infusion of whole plant taken and rubbed on abdomen as an emetic.<ref name="Stevenson_56"/> *''[[Machaeranthera tanacetifolia]]'' (tanseyleaf aster), infusion of flowers taken with other flowers for unspecified illnesses.<ref name="Camazine_375"/> *''[[Mahonia fremontii]]'' (Fremont's mahonia), crushed berries used as purple coloring for the skin and for objects employed in ceremonies.<ref name="Stevenson_88"/> *''[[Mentzelia pumila]]'' (dwarf mentzelia), plant inserted into rectum as a suppository for constipation.<ref name="Stevenson_57"/> Plant used to whip children to make them strong so they could hold on to a horse without falling.<ref name="Stevenson_84"/> *''[[Mirabilis linearis]]'' (narrowleaf four o'clock), root eaten to induce urination and vomiting. Infusion of the root taken for stomachache.<ref name="Camazine_377"/> *''[[Mirabilis multiflora]]'' (Colorado four o'clock), powdered root mixed with flour, made into a bread and used to decrease appetite.<ref name="Camazine_377"/> Infusion of root taken and rubbed on abdomen of hungry adults and children.<ref>[[#Stevenson|Stevenson]], pp. 58–59.</ref> Infusion of powdered root taken by adults or children after overeating.<ref>[[#Stevenson|Stevenson]], p. 58.</ref> *''[[Muhlenbergia rigens]]'' (deergrass), grass attached to sticks of plume offerings to anthropic gods.<ref name="Stevenson_91"/>
==N== *''[[Nicotiana attenuata]]'' (coyote tobacco), the smoke of which is blown over the body to reduce the throbbing from rattlesnake bite.<ref name="Stevenson_54"/> It is also smoked ceremonially.<ref>[[#Stevenson|Stevenson]], p. 95.</ref>
==O== *''[[Oenothera albicaulis]]'' (whitish evening primrose), the chewed blossoms of which are rubbed on the bodies of young girls so that they can dance well and ensure rain.<ref name="Stevenson_87"/> *''[[Oenothera coronopifolia]]'' (crownleaf evening primrose), poultice of powdered flower and saliva applied at night to swellings.<ref name="Camazine_377"/> *''[[Oenothera elata|Oenothera elata, ssp. hookeri]]'' (Hooker's evening primrose), poultice of powdered flower and saliva applied at night to swellings.<ref name="Camazine_377"/> *''[[Oenothera triloba]]'' (stemless evening primrose), ingredient of "schumaakwe cakes" and used externally for rheumatism and swelling.<ref name="Stevenson, p.55">Stevenson, p.55</ref> The roots are also ground and used as food.<ref>Reagan, Albert B. 1929 Plants Used by the White Mountain Apache Indians of Arizona. Wisconsin Archeologist 8:143-61. (p. 158)</ref> *''[[Opuntia imbricata|Opuntia imbricata var. imbricata]]'' (tree cholla), used ceremonially.<ref name="Stevenson, p.95">Stevenson, p.95</ref> *''[[Opuntia whipplei]]'' (whipple cholla), fruits, with the spines rubbed off, are dried for winter use.<ref name="Stevenson, p.69">Stevenson, p.69</ref> Spineless fruits are eaten raw or stewed.<ref>Castetter, p.36</ref> *''[[Orobanche fasciculata]]'' (clustered broomrape), the powdered plant is inserted into the rectum as a [[hemorrhoid]] remedy.<ref>[[#Stevenson|Stevenson]], p. 61.</ref>
==P== *''[[Pectis papposa]]'' (cinchweed fetidmarigold), the [[Zuni people]] take an infusion of the whole plant as a [[carminative]], and use an infusion of the blossoms as eye drops for [[snowblindness]].<ref name="Stevenson_57">[[#Stevenson|Stevenson]], p. 57.</ref> The Zuni also use the chewed blossoms as perfume before a dance in ceremonies of the secret fraternities.<ref name="Stevenson_83"/> *''[[Penstemon barbatus|Penstemon barbatus ssp. torreyi]]'' (Torrey's penstemon), chewed root rubbed over the rabbit stick to insure success in the hunt.<ref name="Stevenson, p.95"/> *''[[Phacelia neomexicana]]'' (New Mexico scorpionweed), powdered root mixed with water and used for rashes.<ref name="Camazine and Bye, p.376">Camazine and Bye, p.376</ref> *''[[Phaseolus angustissimus]]'' (slimleaf bean), crushed leaves, blossoms and powdered root rubbed on a child's body as a strengthener.<ref name="Stevenson_85"/> *''[[Phaseolus vulgaris]]'' (kidney bean), beans boiled and fried or crushed, boiled beans mixed with mush, baked in corn husks & used for food.<ref name="Stevenson, p.69"/> *''[[Phoradendron juniperinum]]'' (juniper mistletoe), infusion of whole plant used for stomachaches.<ref>Camazine and Bye, p.377</ref> Compound infusion of plant taken to promote muscular relaxation at birth. Simple or compound infusion of twigs taken after childbirth to stop blood flow.<ref name="Stevenson, p.55"/> *''[[Physalis hederifolia|Physalis hederifolia, var fendleri]]'' (Fendler's groundcherry), fruit boiled in small quantities of water, crushed and used as a condiment.<ref name="Stevenson, p.70">Stevenson, p.70</ref> *''[[Physalis longifolia]]'' (longleaf groundcherry), berries boiled, ground in a mortar with raw onions, chile and coriander seeds and used for food.<ref name="Stevenson, p.70"/> *''[[Psoralidium lanceolatum]]'' (lemon scurfpea), fresh flower eaten for stomachaches.<ref name="Camazine and Bye, p.376"/> *''[[Psoralidium tenuiflorum]]'' (slimleaf scurfpea), poultice of moistened leaves applied to any body part for purification.<ref>Stevenson, p.58</ref>
==R== *''[[Ratibida columnifera]]'' (upright prairie coneflower), infusion of whole plant taken as an emetic.<ref>[[#Stevenson|Stevenson]], p. 59.</ref> *''[[Rhus trilobata]]'' (skunkbush sumac), stems with the bark removed used in making baskets.<ref>Stevenson, p.81</ref> *[[Ribes cereum|''Ribes cereum'' var. ''pedicellare'']] (whiskey currant), berries used as food, and leaves eaten with uncooked mutton fat or deer fat.<ref name="Stevenson, p.70"/> *''[[Rorippa sinuata]]'' (spreading yellowcress), infusion of plant used as a wash and smoke from blossoms used for inflamed eyes.<ref name="Stevenson, p.59">Stevenson, p.59</ref> *''[[Rumex crispus]]'' (curly dock), poultice of powdered root applied to sores, rashes and skin infections, and infusion of root used for [[athlete's foot]].<ref name="Camazine and Bye, p.378">Camazine and Bye, p.378</ref> Note: This plant is not native to the Americas, and was introduced. *[[Rumex salicifolius|''Rumex salicifolius'' var. ''mexicanus'']] (Mexican dock), strong infusion of root made and given to women by their husbands to help them to become pregnant.<ref>Stevenson, p.85</ref> Ground root or infusion taken for sore throat, especially by sword swallower.<ref name="Stevenson, p.59"/>
==S== *''[[Salix exigua]]'' (sandbar willow), infusion of bark taken for coughs and sore throats.<ref name="Camazine and Bye, p.378"/> *[[Symphyotrichum falcatum|''Symphyotrichum falcatum'' var. ''commutatum'']] (cluster aster), the ground blossoms are mixed with [[yucca]] suds and used to wash newborn infants to make their hair grow and strengthen them.<ref name="Stevenson_84"/> *[[Symphyotrichum lanceolatum|''Symphyotrichum lanceolatum'' var. ''hesperium'']] (siskiyou aster), a decoction of which is used to dress arrow or bullet wounds. The dried, pulverized plant is used for abrasions from ceremonial masks, and smoke from crushed blossoms is inhaled to treat nosebleed.<ref>[[#Stevenson|Stevenson]], p. 43.</ref>
==T== *''[[Tetraneuris scaposa]]'' (stemmy hymenoxys), an infusion of which is used as an eyewash. It is not for people with a "bad heart".<ref>[[#Stevenson|Stevenson]], pp. 60–61.</ref>
==V== *''[[Verbascum thapsus]]'' (common mullein), a poultice of powdered root is applied to sores, rashes and skin infections. An infusion of the root is also used to treat [[athlete's foot]].<ref name="Camazine_378"/> Note: This plant is not native to the Americas, and was introduced.
==X== *[[Xanthium strumarium|''Xanthium strumarium'' var. ''canadense'']] (Canada cockleburr), the chewed seeds are rubbed onto the body before the cactus ceremony to protect it from vines. A compound poultice of seeds is applied to wounds or used to remove splinters.<ref>[[#Stevenson|Stevenson]], pp. 62–63.</ref> The seeds are also ground, mixed with cornmeal, made into cakes, and steamed for food.<ref>[[#Stevenson|Stevenson]], p. 71.</ref><ref>[[#Castetter|Castetter]], p. 54.</ref>
==Y== *''[[Yucca glauca]]'' (small soapweed), seed pods boiled and used for food.<ref>[[#Stevenson|Stevenson]], p. 73.</ref> Leaves are made into brushes & used for decorating pottery, ceremonial masks, altars and other objects.<ref name="Stevenson_82"/> Leaves are also soaked in water to soften them and made into rope by knotting them together.<ref name="Stevenson_79">[[#Stevenson|Stevenson]], p. 79.</ref> Dried leaves are split, plaited and made into water-carrying head pads.<ref>[[#Bell|Bell & Castetter]], p. 47.</ref> Leaves are also used for making mats, cincture pads and other articles.<ref name="Stevenson_79"/> The peeled roots pounded, made into suds and used for washing the head, wool garments and blankets.<ref name="Stevenson_83"/>
==Z== *''[[Zinnia grandiflora]]'' (Rocky Mountain zinnia), applied in a poultice to bruises, cold infusion of blossoms used as an eyewash, and smoke from powdered plant inhaled in sweatbath for fever.<ref name="Stevenson_45"/>
